Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Antibiotics Versus Placebo for Uncomplicated Acute Appendicitis

Trial_Design.evidence: double-blind, placebo-controlled, superiority randomised controlled trial

Participants.evidence: participants aged 18-60 years with uncomplicated acute appendicitis were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive either antibiotics (intravenous ertapenem followed by oral levofloxacin and metronidazole) or placebo

Objective.evidence: aimed to assess the efficacy of antibiotics compared to placebo in adults with CT-confirmed uncomplicated acute appendicitis

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was treatment success, defined as resolution of appendicitis without appendicectomy within 10 days

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by centre, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and clinicians were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: From May 2017 to September 2020, 72 patients were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: Six were excluded post-randomisation due to early consent withdrawal or protocol violation

Result_Outcome.evidence: The treatment success rate was 97% (34/35) for antibiotics and 87% (27/31) for placebo, with a non-significant difference of 10% (90% CI -0.9 to 21; p = 0.142)

Harms.evidence: No deaths occurred, and adverse events were similar between groups
